_data.text:
### Description Dichotomy is a turn-based competitive board/strategy game that could be played between 2 to 6 players in which players make choices at each step, taking into account the behavior of the other players. To win the game, good strategy with the factor of luck must be present together. The game can be played at different difficulty levels depending on the preference of the player group. __Disclaimer:__ The game draft is in the hypothetical phase. As it has not been tested, it may contain unforeseen logical problems or imbalanced cases. ### Setup The game space is created through combining hexagonal cards (module or dichotomy cards) to form a big hexagon form (map or board). Dichotomy cards are arranged randomly on the hexagonal game map. This condition introduces the factor of luck and creates an slightly different variation for each game. Map size is adjusted to include 13 module cards on the diagonal. Each session is aimed to last between 25-40 minutes to avoid the game becoming repetitive and overwhelming. ![Game Board](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/gameboard.png)
Figure 1: Gameboard
Each player starts on a corner of the hexagonal map. Players' positions relative to each other are positioned so that they are uniformly distributed across the game board. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/player_placement.png)
Figure 2: Player Placement
### Mechanics Each player starts the game with five basic stats. These are Health, Hunger, Stamina, Strength and Speed. Dichotomy cards show the player's position on the map. Only one player can be on a card at a time. Rotating on clockwise, players move by choosing one of the cards adjacent to their current dichotomy card. Each dichotomy card gives one negative and one positive property, e.g. +1 speed, -1 hunger. Players have stats that affected by dichotomy cards. | Icon | Stat | Limit |Description | |-----------------|-------------------------|-------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | ![health](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/health.png) | Heal | 6 | Allows to player endure bad conditions if reaches zero, player dies. | | ![hunger](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/hunger.png) | Hunger | 6 | Decreases one on each step if reaches zero player dies. | | ![strength](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/strength.png) | Strength | 4 | Power of player to handle encounters. Either against card or players. | | ![stamina](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/stamina.png) | Stamina | 4 | Decreases one on each step. If zero player must one turn to gain. | | ![speed](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/speed.png) | Speed | 3 | Determines how many tiles player could move at once. |
Table 1: Player Stats
![Player Movement](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/player_movement.png)
Figure 3: Player Movement
__Tracking player stats__ Each player gets a player card that has slot for cardriges of each stat. As player moves on the dichotomy card, one applies the stat changes on their card by giving/taking color distincted stat cardridges. Player cannot fill more than maximum amount of the stat. Each player should explicitly show their stat cards to other players. ![Player Sheet and Cartridges](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/player_sheet.png)
Figure 4: Player Sheet and Stat Cartridges
__The game can be won in more in various ways__ - By eliminating all the other players - Reaching the safe zone in the middle - By visiting 3 players starting place and acquiring their spawnstones. __Dichotomy Cards__ are step-over decisions that affects player stats. It contains minimum 3 basic information. These are: name of the card, positive aspect, and negative aspect. __Dichotomy Card Levels__ There are three groups of dichotomy cards distinguished by color. These groups are there to prevent players from moving around the map with uniform ease, and to create some alignment rules to prevent randomization from creating cul de sac situations that players lose at the early game. In other words, randomization is intended to introduce the factor of luck into the game, whereas alignment rules are there to prevent chance rom being the dominant factor and overriding the player's preferences. | Color | Level | Desciption | |------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Green | Easy | Regular trade-off | | Yellow | Medium | Unfair trade-off | | Orange | Hard | Extremely unfair trade-off | __Step over preventation__ The card the player steps on is flipped over and grayed out. This card loses its effect until the player exits the adjacent cards. At the end of each round the non-adjacent cards are reactivated. In order to win the game, the player needs to create a progressive strategy by balancingg their stats on the maps and reading the actions of the other players. ![Dichotomy Card](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/dichotomy_card.png)
Figure 5: Dichotomy card (Back and Front)
__Dichotomy Card Examples__ | Name | Positive Aspect | Negative Aspect | |------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Hunt | +1 Hunger | -1 Stamina | | Stay | +1 Energy | -1 Hunger, No movement | | Training | +1 Strength | -1 Stamina, -1 Hunger | | Teleport | -2 Energy, -1 Speed | Move to desired location | | Portal | -1 Energy, -1 Hunger | Move to designated location (other portal) | | ... | ... | ... | - Variations of dichotomy card is to be added considering the balance to extend the complexity of game. __Player versus Player__ Player could attack and kill other players. To hit another player, target player should be in the attack range by the player. Attacking another player costs 1 hunger and energy equal to players strength. If attacker players energy lesser than his/her strength, then player hit strength is regarded equivalent to as his/her stamina. Hit amount is decreased from attacked player's health. If it the health of attacked player reaches zero. Attacked player dies and attacker takes the position of attacked player, otherwise positions stays same. ### Modes and Variations - **Complexity Level 1:** - There are certain single-use items added on the map with some rules. That enhances the stats extensively beyond limits, or provides unique abiltiy - ex. bow, bicycle etc. - **Complexity Level 2:** - Players have a technology tree and materials among map to create items in complexity level 2. - ex. Research cooking, weapon craft - **Immortal mode:** - the killed player reborns on starting zone. Loses his collected spawnstones ### Story In a post-apocalyptic world, there is scarce of sources to accommodate all. Survivalists compete against each other against each other to live. ### Theory The statement _decisions comes with trade-offs_ holds the subtle message of this game. One of the principles that I have adopted in the late stage of my life as I have learned through experience. I encounter often the falsification about the perception of the concept of decision. As it to be regarded something to gain but at the same time not to lose. A decision, choosing one of the two or more options. It opens up a new path, but it also means that other paths are closed. It might seem about a cruel reality. Yet it bear an austere elegance and beauty because decisions are the mere qualities of character that describes who we are. Accepting the responsibility of two-sided condition of a decision not only make us more mature but progress as a being. As a result, the game aimed to express the statement in an entertaining way. ### References and Credits __Visual References__ 1. All figures in the article produced by the author. 2. Icons used in **Table 1** is from _Shikashi's Fantasy Icons Pack_. Images are manipulated by the author. __Used Assets__ 1. _Shikashi's Fantasy Icons Pack_. n.d. Accessed (25-Jan-2023) https://cheekyinkling.itch.io/shikashis-fantasy-icons-pack __Used Sources__ 1. Blender Hand Drawn Shader Tutorial. _Littlerolz - Youtube_ [Video File]. 2019. Accessed (19-Jan-2023) https://youtu.be/YDHGm1W0A-c 2. Hexagon World with Geometry Nodes Fields - Blender 3.0 Tutorial. _Erindale - Youtube_ [Video File]. 2022. Accessed (19-Jan-2023) https://youtu.be/EboNtLKn_m8 __Used Programs__ 1. Adobe Photoshop CC 2. Blender 3.4.1

_data.title: Swapfold

children.value: Swapfold is a single player origami puzzle/storyline-rpg mix top-down platformer game with a unique fundamental feature. Players must replicate actions on real world in order to find some solutions to puzzles. The main idea of the game to establishing a ground to show that games has potential as an environment to be a platform of education. On the completition of the game player should be able to learn few origami pieces through the method of associative learning.
Figure 1: Basic level origamis selected for each chapter

Our player is an apprentice mage who has to train portals. His supervisor gives him extraordinary tasks to complete. In order to understand how interdimensionality works you should be able to accurately represent and simulate them in simple dimensions. Idea comes from quartenions. So he/she starts to learn to play with simple tasks. However, during one of his tasks something goes wrong and a portal opens to demonic world of caridia. Now our characters needs to focus on his training to overcome this problem.

Gameplay starts with a simple platformer game with moving around and exploring the world. With a simple mixed combat and puzzle feature for complex spells. Like a cookbook analogy in programming our character learns simple unitary modular folding techniques to create simple origami pieces, each of which associated with a power word, that could be used combine and casts spells ingame (ultima online / magicka / skyrim).  This techniques progresss further on a skill tree. It is aimed that the skill tree also resembles what player learned in real life as well. On eah chapter player requires to create an origami piece. Writing a mark on number on each fold. At the end opening crafted orgami piece on 2D reveals a map on how to solve a puzzle in game.

Each power word is associated with a folding technique. Player uses keyboard shortcuts to cast power words. Spells are usually combination of (usually 3 or 4) few power words. In rpg combat player must cast spells. A complex set of power words represent portals as well as origami pieces.
Each power word is learned through a simple puzzle.
Figure 2: Fold and Power Word Asssociation on Skill Tree
Basic game mechanics is a adjusted combination of two main mechanics. Those are moderate paced, environmentally interactive topdown rpg game play and puzzle solving.
Each spell is combination of one or more power words. During rpg combat, player uses the combination of power words through
to cast spell to overcome challenges. This combinations further helps player to solve puzzles through replicating origami pieces in real life.
Example systems in real games (ultima online, skyrim, magicka)
Casting a spell requires a small amount of time. Each cast process has three periods. Those are:
states represents a failing cast. If player ends casts too early, spell fizzles, simply fails without any effect. After the end of fizzle,
period begins. During success, effect of spell increases exponantially until until excession period. The latest stage of the cast is
state is guaranteed failing cast and harms the player depending on the combination of spells. The harm is maximum at start and decreases parabolically up to half of maximum success effect.
Figure 3: Spell Effect Change In Relation To Cast Periods

On the combinations, different power words affect the cast time and proportions of the cast periods. Along with the mastery and usage frequency of the player.
Through the mix of spell word combination and progressive casting, it is aimed to create create precision input button combos, fun to play but hard to master base combat mechanics of the game.

Player requires to solve a puzzle a to unlock, final chapter battles in game. A typical puzzle is again combination of power words, ingredients or keys to be used on certain sequence or places. This sequence is revealed through creating an origami piece through instructions explored in sub-chapters. On each fold player writes a power word on paper in real world. After completing and unfolding the origami piece, map for solving the puzzle is revealed. The sequence of instructions, and words are randomized to create unique map for each instance of the game.
Game consist of chapters each chapters corresponds an origami piece, and chapters consists of sub-chapters each of one corresponds to fold-technique.

During sub-chapter with different hints player learns origami by retrieves knowledge such as which fold-technique to be used, how many times and where. Player could replicate this information step to create origami piece.
On certain steps, player are given some additional power words (as runes) for portal keys. On this case, the given rune needs to be written on  indicated area before applying the fold.

Completing the chapter, will result to complete the origami as well. However, to unlock next chapter, player requires to handle a boss fight. The boss fight room always resembles the unfolded paper of origami piece. On certain periods, boss stops and an area is indicated by color or light. On this time player should go to given area and cast the true power word.
If player had replicated given fold techniques in real life, unfolding the origami should reveal the true power words, in that player could use true power word to cast the portal.
Upon completing successful rpg boss fight with the combination of origami puzzle player defeats the boss and gains access to the new chapter. Along with learning an origami in real life.
Description selected origami for the chapter as a composition of folding steps.
Decision on which steps to write a power rune on fold.
Writing of appropriate questline for each fold and rune to reveal map.
Design of boss fight mechanics and space that bears resemblance of unfolded origami.

As a general principle, it is aimed to increase the interaction with the environment for player. Environment is not only frozen entity to move and orient for next encounter but also, something to be aware of and act depending of the requirements of the place. Player should be able to change, alter or impact on the environment. At the same time strategicaly use it for personal progression.
Frost based spells has multipliers to hit greater to wet enemies.
Player should avoid using fire spells on environment with dry woods to create fire.
Player should position themselves tactically to avoid impact boulder rolls, and even use this phenomenon to encounter with enemies.

One of the problems that I have encountered in online games, that crafted objects costs lesser than material itself. Which is often wrong compared to the real world. The problem is gathering costs labor, however crafting does not, as a result since the material has variety of usage it worth more. To compete with this problem. It is aimed to set alternative progression mechanics such as crafting to be supported by engraved mini games to include and value them in labor. On further extreme, who whole complex game could be considered as a composition of mini games too.
Lockpicking mechanism in Elder Scrolls series.

The mechanic requirements to solve puzzles or progression is aimed to be engraved in-game as much as possible. Player should not progress with grind with frozen state of mind, but immerse him/herself in the game content and try to solve a problem to make a progress.
Trolls could be killed by using fire spells learned through a book (Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, 2011)

On crafting, player must adjust the necessary conditions to create best possible variations of weapon. This information could be retrieved from someone, or something from ingame. To avoid duplication of the solution outside of the game. Given sources are randomized every game. On example, to forge a good sword, player should set the temperature to correct level. The level is described as a color of something (for instance a peach) ingame by someone or some text. Player should get a peach to compare colors to see correct level adjustment.

Another factor to establish an immersive environment is to push player to think and theorycraft the problem space created in-game. To create this environment, I consider, technology, and skill trees are good method to create complexity and considering people to think over variances and new possibilities to play and interract with the game. However, I belive skills trees should not shadow the players control over the character. Fundamental success should still be binded to player.

A time system tracks day/night cycles and calendar to set events. To bind sense of time to certain events such as puzzles or social/unique events ingame that enhances to create more surrounding environment in parallelity with the idea of Gesamkunstwerk.

As a fundamental aspect of any role-playing game inventory system is aimed to include in Swapfold. To be able to progress on character, use of materials to create more powerful objects and increase environmental interaction.

Describing environment as modules and computationally bind this parts to describe seamlessly transitive places. The idea is to create relatively unique experience on each seed, as well as preventing the rote progression.
Example games using described system: Diablo series, Valheim, Don't Starve
Map randomization: As a part of prodecural environment creation parts of the map is randomly customized
Puzzle randomization: To prevent same written guide to pass the game without playing it. The fold hints are given randomly to form a unique form for each puzzle instance.
Basic level origamis selected for each chapter. Figure produced by the author. 2023.
Fold and Power Word Asssociation on Skill Tree. Figure produced by the author. 2023.
Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Power Words
Spell Effect Change In Relation To Cast Periods. Figure produced by the author. 2023.
Periods of Cast Bar. Figure produced by the author. 2023.
Puzzle Solving Steps Depiction. Figure produced by the author. 2023.
Visualizing quaternions (4d numbers) with stereographic projection
The Cookbook Method of Learning Programming Languages
Lucareilli, C.D.C., Carlo, J. "Parametric modeling simulation for an origami shaped canopy".
Pelley, M.E.Le. "The role of associative history in models of associative learning: a selective review and a hybrid model".
Electronic Arts, Origin Systems, Mythic Entertainment.

_data.text:
### | Description Swapfold is a single player origami puzzle/storyline-rpg mix top-down platformer game with a unique fundamental feature. Players must replicate actions on real world in order to find some solutions to puzzles. The main idea of the game to establishing a ground to show that games has potential as an environment to be a platform of education. On the completition of the game player should be able to learn few origami pieces through the method of associative learning. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/chapters.png)
Figure 1: Basic level origamis selected for each chapter
### | Story Our player is an apprentice mage who has to train portals. His supervisor gives him extraordinary tasks to complete. In order to understand how interdimensionality works you should be able to accurately represent and simulate them in simple dimensions. Idea comes from quartenions. So he/she starts to learn to play with simple tasks. However, during one of his tasks something goes wrong and a portal opens to demonic world of caridia. Now our characters needs to focus on his training to overcome this problem. ### | Base Gameplay Gameplay starts with a simple platformer game with moving around and exploring the world. With a simple mixed combat and puzzle feature for complex spells. Like a cookbook analogy in programming our character learns simple unitary modular folding techniques to create simple origami pieces, each of which associated with a power word, that could be used combine and casts spells ingame (ultima online / magicka / skyrim). This techniques progresss further on a skill tree. It is aimed that the skill tree also resembles what player learned in real life as well. On eah chapter player requires to create an origami piece. Writing a mark on number on each fold. At the end opening crafted orgami piece on 2D reveals a map on how to solve a puzzle in game. Each power word is associated with a folding technique. Player uses keyboard shortcuts to cast power words. Spells are usually combination of (usually 3 or 4) few power words. In rpg combat player must cast spells. A complex set of power words represent portals as well as origami pieces. Each power word is learned through a simple puzzle. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/skill_tree.png)
Figure 2: Fold and Power Word Asssociation on Skill Tree
### | Mechanics Basic game mechanics is a adjusted combination of two main mechanics. Those are moderate paced, environmentally interactive topdown rpg game play and puzzle solving. __Spell Word Combinations__ Each spell is combination of one or more power words. During rpg combat, player uses the combination of power words through _button combos_ to cast spell to overcome challenges. This combinations further helps player to solve puzzles through replicating origami pieces in real life. Example systems in real games (ultima online, skyrim, magicka) __Progressive Casting__ Casting a spell requires a small amount of time. Each cast process has three periods. Those are: _fizzle_, _success_, _excession_. With the analogy of cooking, _fizzle_ states represents a failing cast. If player ends casts too early, spell fizzles, simply fails without any effect. After the end of fizzle, _success_ period begins. During success, effect of spell increases exponantially until until excession period. The latest stage of the cast is _excession_ period. _Excession_ state is guaranteed failing cast and harms the player depending on the combination of spells. The harm is maximum at start and decreases parabolically up to half of maximum success effect. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/cast_graph.png)
Figure 3: Spell Effect Change In Relation To Cast Periods
On the combinations, different power words affect the cast time and proportions of the cast periods. Along with the mastery and usage frequency of the player. Through the mix of spell word combination and progressive casting, it is aimed to create create precision input button combos, fun to play but hard to master base combat mechanics of the game. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/cast_bar.png)
Figure 4: Periods of Cast Bar
__Real World Replication__ Player requires to solve a puzzle a to unlock, final chapter battles in game. A typical puzzle is again combination of power words, ingredients or keys to be used on certain sequence or places. This sequence is revealed through creating an origami piece through instructions explored in sub-chapters. On each fold player writes a power word on paper in real world. After completing and unfolding the origami piece, map for solving the puzzle is revealed. The sequence of instructions, and words are randomized to create unique map for each instance of the game. __Example Puzzle Chapter__ - Game consist of chapters each chapters corresponds an origami piece, and chapters consists of sub-chapters each of one corresponds to fold-technique. - During sub-chapter with different hints player learns origami by retrieves knowledge such as which fold-technique to be used, how many times and where. Player could replicate this information step to create origami piece. - On certain steps, player are given some additional power words (as runes) for portal keys. On this case, the given rune needs to be written on indicated area before applying the fold. - Completing the chapter, will result to complete the origami as well. However, to unlock next chapter, player requires to handle a boss fight. The boss fight room always resembles the unfolded paper of origami piece. On certain periods, boss stops and an area is indicated by color or light. On this time player should go to given area and cast the true power word. - If player had replicated given fold techniques in real life, unfolding the origami should reveal the true power words, in that player could use true power word to cast the portal. - Upon completing successful rpg boss fight with the combination of origami puzzle player defeats the boss and gains access to the new chapter. Along with learning an origami in real life. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/mapping.png)
Figure 5: Puzzle Solving Steps Depiction
__Puzzle Generation Steps__ 1. Description selected origami for the chapter as a composition of folding steps. 2. Decision on which steps to write a power rune on fold. 3. Writing of appropriate questline for each fold and rune to reveal map. 4. Design of boss fight mechanics and space that bears resemblance of unfolded origami. ### | Theory __Environmental Interactions__ As a general principle, it is aimed to increase the interaction with the environment for player. Environment is not only frozen entity to move and orient for next encounter but also, something to be aware of and act depending of the requirements of the place. Player should be able to change, alter or impact on the environment. At the same time strategicaly use it for personal progression. Example cases: - Frost based spells has multipliers to hit greater to wet enemies. - Player should avoid using fire spells on environment with dry woods to create fire. - Player should position themselves tactically to avoid impact boulder rolls, and even use this phenomenon to encounter with enemies. __Integrated Mini Games__ One of the problems that I have encountered in online games, that crafted objects costs lesser than material itself. Which is often wrong compared to the real world. The problem is gathering costs labor, however crafting does not, as a result since the material has variety of usage it worth more. To compete with this problem. It is aimed to set alternative progression mechanics such as crafting to be supported by engraved mini games to include and value them in labor. On further extreme, who whole complex game could be considered as a composition of mini games too. Example cases: - Progressive casting mechanism given above. - Lockpicking mechanism in Elder Scrolls series. - Hacking in Eve Online. __Internal Learning Mechanism__ The mechanic requirements to solve puzzles or progression is aimed to be engraved in-game as much as possible. Player should not progress with grind with frozen state of mind, but immerse him/herself in the game content and try to solve a problem to make a progress. Example casees: - Trolls could be killed by using fire spells learned through a book (Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, 2011) - On crafting, player must adjust the necessary conditions to create best possible variations of weapon. This information could be retrieved from someone, or something from ingame. To avoid duplication of the solution outside of the game. Given sources are randomized every game. On example, to forge a good sword, player should set the temperature to correct level. The level is described as a color of something (for instance a peach) ingame by someone or some text. Player should get a peach to compare colors to see correct level adjustment. __Technology and Skill Trees__ Another factor to establish an immersive environment is to push player to think and theorycraft the problem space created in-game. To create this environment, I consider, technology, and skill trees are good method to create complexity and considering people to think over variances and new possibilities to play and interract with the game. However, I belive skills trees should not shadow the players control over the character. Fundamental success should still be binded to player. __Environmental Interactions__ ### | Sub Systems __Time and Date__ A time system tracks day/night cycles and calendar to set events. To bind sense of time to certain events such as puzzles or social/unique events ingame that enhances to create more surrounding environment in parallelity with the idea of Gesamkunstwerk. __Inventory__ As a fundamental aspect of any role-playing game inventory system is aimed to include in Swapfold. To be able to progress on character, use of materials to create more powerful objects and increase environmental interaction. __Procedural Environment Generation__ Describing environment as modules and computationally bind this parts to describe seamlessly transitive places. The idea is to create relatively unique experience on each seed, as well as preventing the rote progression. - Example games using described system: Diablo series, Valheim, Don't Starve __Controlled Randomization__ - Map randomization: As a part of prodecural environment creation parts of the map is randomly customized - Puzzle randomization: To prevent same written guide to pass the game without playing it. The fold hints are given randomly to form a unique form for each puzzle instance. ### | References __Visual References__ 1. _Figure 1._ Basic level origamis selected for each chapter. _data.title: Alteration on Roles of the Architect in Contemporary Social Context
_data.keywords: autonomy of architecture; altermodernity; architecture and politics; political dystopia; deprogression

toc.text: Confusion of Meaning of Architect In the Society
Role of Architect in the Contemporary World
Critique of Social Paradoxes of Present-Day
Excluding Architecture from Production of Built Environment

children.value:
The scope of this article is to interrogate ill-defined social paradox that resulting
non-functioning built environment within the framework of cause-effect relationship,
highlight the possible negative outcomes of given situation, pointing out discussions on the
role of architects and performance or control mechanisms in order to be able to create better
built environment.

The anthropocentric point of view gradually became prevailing paradigm in the world by
chain reaction initialized after period of Renaissance as a projection to this, especially since
19th Century role of architect gradually reshaped as rather than being servant to elite or
authority they gained autonomy and identical significance at some extend as discourse of
modernism promised to offer solutions for problems of contemporary world (e.g.
overpopulation, technological improvements, wars, enormously grown cities, migration et
cetera) and steer the new world society. Moreover as Kate Nesbitt points out paradigms

in
which postmodern discourse built upon, focused even more on fixation and rectification of
social paradoxes and complications.

However in 21th Century it would not be wrong to say that is unable to follow traces of
humanitarian aspects in contemporary cities. The touch of architect is concrete on buildings
of prestige such as museums, airports, opera houses and skyscrapers; but rarely visible on
residential areas, stations, schools and community zones. In other words, places of everyday
life in which people spend most of their times are not receiving the necessary attention during
the design process of built environment. As a result mass production occurring as copying
which could be considered as failure in different aspects. On phenomenological perspective,
Christian Norberg-Schulz pointed out “Genius Loci” as he states:

Man dwells when he can orientate himself within and identify himself within
environment, or, in short, when he experiences the environment as a meaningful.
Dwelling therefore implies something more than ‘shelter”. It implies that the spaces
where life occurs are places, in the true sense of the word. A place is space which has
a distinct character. Since ancient times the genius loci, or “spirit of place”, has been
recognized as the concrete reality man has to face and come to terms with in his daily
life. Architecture means to visualize the genius loci, and the task of the architect is to
create meaningful places, whereby he helps man to dwell. (Norberg-Schulz, 1979)

In this scrutiny, by pointing out Genius Loci, Norberg-Schulz criticizes the what discourse of
modernism stripped off from built environments mostly caused by inappropriate application
of mass production even if the intentions were opposite. Another aspect of failure unfolded
by Kevin Lynch by this terms “imageability” and “wayfinding” as he states:

A distinctive and legible environment not only offers security but also heightens the
potential depth and intensity of human experience. Although life is far from impossible
in the visual chaos of the modern city, the same daily action could take on new meaning
if carried out in a more vivid setting. (Lynch, 1960)

Being not able to provide necessary attention to design would also result to generation of
non-distinctive places which will prevent people from orienting themselves in the city. As a
result experiencing the city is not a valid notion anymore especially for Generation Z

as it
turned out something to afraid of, a subject of obscurity itself.

However shaping built environment that way is not the choice of architect. Whereas
architecture is directly related with politics, production of built environment is affected by
complex social paradox in which especially in non-developed countries the scope of
production prioritize income rather than life that place has to provide. Additionally
significance of urban design and autonomy of architecture is underestimated. Therefore, they
are excluded from the production of built environment which they has to be autonomous at
some extend. In fact even previously mentioned “prestige buildings” are not an exception for
the situation. The main reason behind being point of interest is marginal advertising potential
(i.e. Profit opportunities) which intended and designated by authoritative power of the capital.
Therefore another intention of modernism turns out as failure as relation with authority does
not changed but shifted it is figurative form to abstract phenomenon.

In this paper main scope is to interrogate ill-defined social paradox that resulting
non-functioning built environment, identify negative qualitative outcomes of situation and
pointing out discussions on role of architects and simulating performance or control
mechanisms in order to be able to create better built environment.

Meaning is an evolving phenomenon by time, culture and society. Additionally, the
multidisciplinary nature of architecture makes the context of its meaning fragile. In different
intervals of history, architecture partially overlapped by context of engineering, artistry and
craftsmanship. However changes the zones of overlapping, architecture kept its genuine
intersection zone and defined itself as autonomous discipline. Nonetheless, for further
discussions it is beneficial to point out differing point between artist and architect as Le
Corbusier states:

The engineer and the architect have to work with other people’s money. They must
consider their clients and, like politicians,they cannot be too far ahead of their moment.
The artist, on the other hand particularly the painter, may generally find it nearly
impossible to live; but if he is able to establish one of those curious compromises by
means of which he can carry on a lean existence, he is at least free (at times) to project
himself on paper or canvas without necessary reference to anything or anybody; and to
make experiment and research for its own sake. (Le Corbusier, 1927)

As Le Corbusier pointed the difference; the architect distinguish from the artist at point that
former has only bounded freedom so content of architect’s work is cannot be discussed
independent from social context.
Confusion of Meaning of Architect In the Society

The chain reaction of events started by enlightenment and followed by industrial revolution
resulted the emergence new transitionary social class. Social structure changed by revolutions

, demanded a built environment to serve life rather than given public space. In 19th century
by the redefinition of modernity architects started to be in service of stated demand in
general. On the other hand, by the scale and improvement of building technologies;
professions once they were one under architecture are separated as individual disciplines.
Civil engineering and city planning i.e. urban design could be given examples of this
segregation. A common misunderstanding maybe because of these historical references,
people has confusion about what should they expect from architect or what should be the
responsibilities and competencies of the architect.

In another aspect, it is assumed that people has adequate perception when participating
surveys. However surveys that their methodology bounded to declarations about life
satisfaction or qualities of built environment are not always providing reliable results. For
instance, the one could consider the non-functioning built environment as successful that he
or she living in, by comparing with the worse only because of that being not capable to
imagine qualitative superior which architect could provide. Therefore, it is important to
educate people about the context of discipline of architecture in order to be able to foundate
participatory

production of built environment. By healthy feedbacks qualities of built
environment could be improved ,by teaching the capabilities of design; demand and
cultivation for urban aesthetics

may be provided, welfare, life quality, hygiene, adaptability
(in terms of flora and fauna) and flexibility standards could be expanded.
Role of Architect in the Contemporary World

It is not possible to fit perpetually evolving phenomenon in rigidly defined boundaries.
However it is necessity to make a description in order to be able to comprehend the notion
and articulate within the scope of objectivity, fit in the context of social integrity and
jurisprudence. Therefore, to concretize by raw description in contemporary world, ideally,
role of architecture could be summarized to serve society by creating creative, functioning,
adaptive, flexible and pleasing built environment in the scale of autonomous structure
complexes which also can speak multidimensional level and has a harmonious role within
environment it belongs. Thereby it is important to incarnate the line between other roles
involving the production of built environment. In order to point out contextual meaning of
discipline of architecture Canan Seyhun states:

When regarded as a discipline, it is necessary to evaluate architecture with regard to
its various interrelationships. The discipline of architecture has a multidimensional
character, which assimilates with many theoretical and practical realities. It is possible
to consider architecture as an art, a profession, a science, or as a discourse; and
therefore, it is possible to evaluate an architectural work by means of its many levels;
such as its conceptual, artistic, intellectual, and utilitarian levels. An architectural
work could be evaluated as an art object; having its own aesthetic characteristics, or as
a cultural product; reflecting the conditions of the society, or as a utilitarian
apparatus; satisfying the necessities of intended functions. Not only the tectonic
properties but also the theoretical origins of it could be assessed. (Seyhun, 2004)

Thus, with accurate precision Seyhun identifies boundaries of discipline within the scope of
completeness and correctness. In 21. Century on intellectual level architects actions evolving
into being curators, activists and critics rather than being in active role of shaping built
environment. Reasons of stated situation will be articulated in next chapter.
Critique of Social Paradoxes of Present-Day

In present-day production of built environment is outcome of complex social structure which
previously mentioned as ill-defined paradox. According to Pava: “Social paradox is a
pervasive, continuing dilemma between incompatible yet interdependent activities (i.e.
between regulators and the regulated).” (Pava, 1981)

Present-day examples and outcomes will be discussed upon two exaggerated limit points by
opposite perspectives. The former will articulate the absolute autonomy of architect, while
the latter will mention bypassing the autonomy of architecture i.e. excluding the architect
from its product.

As previously mentioned, since 19th century the architect gained its own autonomy; in fact
with its expanded jurisdiction, arguably the architect itself turned into a figure of authority
which could be explained by lack of control mechanism. Thus, practices of modernus

began
to behave in compulsive attitude rather than given promises of offering a new life, which also
could be supported by bearing of the discourse of postmodernism. However, following
interval did not progressed but shifted the situation. The birth of notion, the Starchitect

could
be an example. Maybe unconsciously but architecture turned out, or at least prioritized being
an object of self-representation instead of the representation of authoritative power.

Individuals may choose not to interact with art objects, but this is not a valid case for
architecture. Thus, unlike the artist who has absolute freedom, the architect cannot prioritize
self-representation in its work. Architecture itself could become an art object; however, since
it has to serve people or bear a social responsibility it has some constraints in which
distinguishes it from an individual art object. In another fold, such attitude also disrupts
perception of role about architect perceived by the society, as well as the image of architect
for architects of future and blur the participatory production of built environment which
discussed in previous chapter.
Excluding Architecture from Production of Built Environment

As opposed to former second extremum point could be given example as bypassing the
autonomy of architecture. This condition is more tangible in non-developed countries, but
also occurring developed countries as well. Hence at some extent especially in less-developed
societies on intellectual level the role of architect or designer started to be seen as
insignificant or easily be replaced, and some professionals claim for being that replacement.
Changing state of autonomy stated by Michael Hays and Lauren Kogod:

When the issue of autonomy re-emerged in the 70s, architecture was in the peculiar
situation of being eroded from within by having become a service industry completely
determined by the building technology and programmatic demands of the time. On the
other hand, it had been challenged from outside the discipline by behaviorism,
sociology, pseudo-positivist history and pseudo-scientific discourses that tried to
explain architecture away in terms of how people behaved, or what response they
checked off on a questionnaire. Formal issues had given way to these statistical and
operational analyses. Architecture found itself without cultural or disciplinary
specificity... In contemporary vocabulary, we could say that architecture found itself
deterritorialized. It lost its domain; it lost the cultural realm that it had controlled. It
had to, therefore, re-territorialize itself by rediscovering, reasserting or reinventing its
codes. (Hays, 2002)

It is possible to observe in everyday life spaces applications of insufficient or non-functioning
built environment which lack the aspects of quality; especially in terms of intrinsic and
intellectual values. Practically all of the cases has a common point of that excluding or not
giving significant attention to role of architect and urban designer in production of built
environment or even the built environment which has to be designed in order to satisfy its
users needs actually prioritize the income for those who build it. Thereby, it turns out to a
capital market rather than place to live. Besides if society does not have necessary perception
to demand the architecture which described in previous chapter; our built environments
cannot be developed, even deprogression could possibly observed as well as in the civilization itself.
It could be summarized as “We shape our buildings and afterwards our
buildings shape us”. (Churchill, 1941)

The Capital mentioned as decisive power in the production of built environment. However if,
as a fact, the income is fundamental parameter of welfare; why is it should not be the
authority to shape the built environment? Briefly, because of the difference of objectives and
focus of short-term goals. Competency for the Olympics and resulted urban transformations
could be an example for the case.

Even though the primary purpose of being a host city is to serve as the location for
sporting events, there must be much more at stake than merely providing a venue for
sport competitions. Much attention has been given to the economic impact and tourism
impact of hosting the Olympics which stresses the role of the Games themselves. 'What
has been neglected is how the Olympics are related to the long-term goals of the city.
(Hiller, 1998)

Even if the Olympics provides reliable income and fulfill the expectations of the capital, if
not planned adaptively; providing a venue for sport competitions will result derelict gaps
within the urban texture. Therefore egocentric nature of capital economy does not prioritize
life which idealistically, the built environment should provide.

In 21. Century by given reasons, it would be not wrong to say especially in less-developed
countries everyday built environment is lacking intrinsic, intellectual, aesthetic and even
fundamental functional requirements of place It could be said that there is a serious political
and social problem exists in this situation and its negative outcomes could also be seen by
quantitative measurements. Rigidity of built environment enforces society to fit in the
boundaries of what defined as normal

; suburbs as bleak strangling points of city, birth of
exurbs

, preference to live and socialize in virtual dimensions, solitary of people living in
cities, obsession of safety, perception of city as a subject of fear, augmented perception

issues
, crime and rise on mental disorders

could be given as examples. By all means
non-functioning built environment may not be the only reason of those problems but should
be pointed out as one of the major reasons.

When Kaufmann family asked for a house from Frank Lloyd Wright; even if they had some
expectancy in their mind, they probably did not expected that Wright will give them the
opportunity of being able live with the waterfall

. Designers of built environment should 12
have their autonomy since they could decipher the multidimensional requirements of space
and create a work that capable to embody the interdisciplinary values of architecture in
singularity. However, when a system became too autonomous it may be blinded to see the
whole or be tend to exclude features easily which are valuable to others. Thus, it is important
to have control mechanisms to align and improve architectural work in order to be able to
serve society and civilization. In that point participatory design process that Jon Lang argued
could foundate the healthy built environment; but conditions could only provided by
understanding the meaning of architecture and convey it through society.

even the most vicious practices of humanity was 13
arguably better than today in terms of providing leaks for progression. Although we are
rationalized, technologically advanced and consider ourselves as civilized; it would not be
true to say that we are progressed in every aspect. Dystopia differs from the dark times by its
completeness in which there is no more opportunity to change. On the assumption, we do not
see and solve our problems in reality then even if we do not call it, we will start to live in the
modern dystopia.

On the subject of the architecture of the 21. Century, it is crucial to point out, problems of
built environment caused by social paradoxes rather interdisciplinary or other aspects in our
reality. Since the built environment is shaped directly by politics social infrastructure has to
be revealed for being able to diagnose this ill-shaped situation. Additionally, even if it is not
the actual part of design process, since they have to bear social responsibility, architects
should contribute as curators, educators, activists and critics in order to be able to shape our
built environment in more idealistic way and advance our civilization.
[1] Berleant, Arnold & Carlson, Allen (Eds.) (2006). The Aesthetics of Human Environment. Broadview Press, Ontario, Plymouth.

[2] Churchill, Winston (1943). Speech to the House of Commons (28 Oct 1943), on plans for the rebuilding of the Chamber (destroyed by an enemy bomb 10 May 1941). Never Give In! : The best of Winston Churchill’s Speeches, 2003. Hyperion, p. 358. ISBN 1401300561

[3] Foucault, Michel (1965). Madness and Civilization: History of Insanity in the Age of Reason. Translated by Richard Howard from the French. Edited by Paul Rabinow. Random House, New York, pp. ix-13 Retrieved from (7 Jan 2019)
[4] Foucault, Michel (1977). Discipline and Punish: The Birth of The Prison. Translated by Alan Sheridan from the French. Ransom House, New York. Retrieved from (8 Jan 2019)
[5] Goto, Katsushi (2017). Autonomy of Architecture, Architecture of Autonomy. Paper Presented at UIA 2017 Seoul World Architects Congress. Seoul. Retrieved From (7 Jan 2019)

[6] Hays, Michael. K. & Kogod, Lauren (Eds.) (2002). Twenty Projects at the Boundaries of the Architectural Discipline Examined in Relation to the Historical and Contemporary Debates over Autonomy. Perspecta, Vol. 33, Mining Autonomy, 2002. pp. 55-57. doi: 10.2307/1567297. Retrieved from (09 Jan 2018)

[7] Hiller, Harry H. (2007). Post-event Outcomes and the Post-modern Turn: The Olympics and Urban Transformations. The International Journal of the History of Sport Volume 25(14), 2008. doi:10.1080/16184740601154458
[8] Kuhn. Thomas S. (1962). The Structure of Scientific Revolutions (2nd Ed.). The University of Chicago Press, London. Retrieved From (4 Jan 2019)
[9] Lang, Jon (1994). Urban Design the American Experience. Van Nostrand Reinhold, New York.
[10] Le Corbusier, (1927). Towards a New Architecture. Translated by Frederick Etchells from the thirteenth French edition. Dover Publications, New York, 1986. Retrieved from (6 Jan 2019)
[11] Lynch, Kevin (1960). The Image of the City. MIT Press, Cambridge, Massachusetts.
[12] Nesbitt, Kate (1996). Theorizing A New Agenda For Architecture: An Anthology of Architectural Theory 1965-1995. Edited by Kate Nesbitt. Princeton Architectural Press, New York.
[13] Norberg-Schulz, Christian (1979). Genius Loci: Towards A Phenomenology of Architecture. Rizzoli International Publications, New York, 1980.

[14] Pava, Calvin. H. P. (1981). Towards a Concept of Normative Incrementalism: One Prospect for Purposeful Non-synoptic Change in Highly Fragmented Social Systems (Dissertation). University of Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania.

[15] Seyhun, Canan (2004). The Role of the Architect and Autonomy of Architecture: An Inquiry into the Position of the Early Modern Architect and Architecture: Le Corbusier and Maison Curutchet (Master Dissertation). Middle East Technical University, Ankara.
[16] Tyner, James A. (2012). Space Place and Violence: Violence and the Embodied Geographies of Race, Sex, and Gender. Routledge, London. pp. 18-24
See Kate Nesbitt, Theorizing A New Agenda For Architecture: An Anthology of Architectural Theory 1965-1995. Edited by Kate Nesbitt. Princeton Architectural Press, New York. pp. 13-25.
2 Generation Z or Gen Z, refers to generation that typically use the mid-1990s to mid-2000s as starting birth years.
E.g. French Revolution (1789), American Civil War (1861-65), The Indian independence movement, The Turkish War of Independence (1919-22)
See Jon Lang, Urban Design the American Experience. Van Nostrand Reinhold, New York. Chapter 20-24

See Arnold Berleant & Allen Carlson, The Aesthetics of Human Environment. Broadview Press, Ontario, Plymouth. Cultivating an Urban Aesthetic by Arnold Berleant and Multi Sensoriness and the City by Yrjö Sepänmaa
An advocate of modern ideas or theories; a person characterized by modernness of thinking. Retrieved From (6 Jan 2019)

Starchitect is a abbreviation used to describe architects whose celebrity and critical acclaim have transformed them into idols of the architecture world and may even have given them some degree of fame amongst the general public. Retrieved from (6 Jan 2019)
See Michel Foucault, Foucault, Michel (1965). Madness and Civilization: History of Insanity in the Age of Reason. Random House, New York, pp. ix-13
A prosperous area beyond a city's suburbs.
Augmented perception refers to incompatible condition of tracing delusional lifestyle created by media e.g. Manhattan Effect
See Michel Foucault, Foucault, Michel (1977). Discipline and Punish: The Birth of The Prison. Translated by Alan Sheridan from the French. Ransom House, New York.

built environment.

### Confusion of Meaning of Architect In the Society

The chain reaction of events started by enlightenment and followed by industrial revolution
resulted the emergence new transitionary social class. Social structure changed by revolutions[^3]
, demanded a built environment to serve life rather than given public space. In 19th century
by the redefinition of modernity architects started to be in service of stated demand in
general. On the other hand, by the scale and improvement of building technologies;
professions once they were one under architecture are separated as individual disciplines.
Civil engineering and city planning i.e. urban design could be given examples of this
segregation. A common misunderstanding maybe because of these historical references,
people has confusion about what should they expect from architect or what should be the
responsibilities and competencies of the architect.

In another aspect, it is assumed that people has adequate perception when participating
surveys. However surveys that their methodology bounded to declarations about life
satisfaction or qualities of built environment are not always providing reliable results. For
instance, the one could consider the non-functioning built environment as successful that he
or she living in, by comparing with the worse only because of that being not capable to
imagine qualitative superior which architect could provide. Therefore, it is important to
educate people about the context of discipline of architecture in order to be able to foundate
participatory[^4] production of built environment. By healthy feedbacks qualities of built
environment could be improved ,by teaching the capabilities of design; demand and 
cultivation for urban aesthetics[^5] may be provided, welfare, life quality, hygiene, adaptability
(in terms of flora and fauna) and flexibility standards could be expanded.

### Role of Architect in the Contemporary World
It is not possible to fit perpetually evolving phenomenon in rigidly defined boundaries.
However it is necessity to make a description in order to be able to comprehend the notion
and articulate within the scope of objectivity, fit in the context of social integrity and
jurisprudence. Therefore, to concretize by raw description in contemporary world, ideally,
role of architecture could be summarized to serve society by creating creative, functioning,
adaptive, flexible and pleasing built environment in the scale of autonomous structure
complexes which also can speak multidimensional level and has a harmonious role within
environment it belongs. Thereby it is important to incarnate the line between other roles
involving the production of built environment. In order to point out contextual meaning of
discipline of architecture Canan Seyhun states:


    When regarded as a discipline, it is necessary to evaluate architecture with regard to
    its various interrelationships. The discipline of architecture has a multidimensional
    character, which assimilates with many theoretical and practical realities. It is possible
    to consider architecture as an art, a profession, a science, or as a discourse; and
    therefore, it is possible to evaluate an architectural work by means of its many levels;
    such as its conceptual, artistic, intellectual, and utilitarian levels. An architectural
    work could be evaluated as an art object; having its own aesthetic characteristics, or as
    a cultural product; reflecting the conditions of the society, or as a utilitarian
    apparatus; satisfying the necessities of intended functions. Not only the tectonic
    properties but also the theoretical origins of it could be assessed. (Seyhun, 2004)

Thus, with accurate precision Seyhun identifies boundaries of discipline within the scope of
completeness and correctness. In 21. Century on intellectual level architects actions evolving
into being curators, activists and critics rather than being in active role of shaping built
environment. Reasons of stated situation will be articulated in next chapter.

## Critique of Social Paradoxes of Present-Day

In present-day production of built environment is outcome of complex social structure which
previously mentioned as ill-defined paradox. According to Pava: “Social paradox is a
pervasive, continuing dilemma between incompatible yet interdependent activities (i.e.
between regulators and the regulated).” (Pava, 1981)

Present-day examples and outcomes will be discussed upon two exaggerated limit points by
opposite perspectives. The former will articulate the absolute autonomy of architect, while
the latter will mention bypassing the autonomy of architecture i.e. excluding the architect
from its product.

### Absolute Autonomy of Architect

As previously mentioned, since 19th century the architect gained its own autonomy; in fact
with its expanded jurisdiction, arguably the architect itself turned into a figure of authority
which could be explained by lack of control mechanism. Thus, practices of modernus[^6] began
to behave in compulsive attitude rather than given promises of offering a new life, which also
could be supported by bearing of the discourse of postmodernism. However, following
interval did not progressed but shifted the situation. The birth of notion, the Starchitect[^7] could
be an example. Maybe unconsciously but architecture turned out, or at least prioritized being
an object of self-representation instead of the representation of authoritative power.

Individuals may choose not to interact with art objects, but this is not a valid case for
architecture. Thus, unlike the artist who has absolute freedom, the architect cannot prioritize
self-representation in its work. Architecture itself could become an art object; however, since
it has to serve people or bear a social responsibility it has some constraints in which
distinguishes it from an individual art object. In another fold, such attitude also disrupts
perception of role about architect perceived by the society, as well as the image of architect
for architects of future and blur the participatory production of built environment which
discussed in previous chapter.

### Excluding Architecture from Production of Built Environment

As opposed to former second extremum point could be given example as bypassing the
autonomy of architecture. This condition is more tangible in non-developed countries, but
also occurring developed countries as well. Hence at some extent especially in less-developed
societies on intellectual level the role of architect or designer started to be seen as
insignificant or easily be replaced, and some professionals claim for being that replacement.
Changing state of autonomy stated by Michael Hays and Lauren Kogod:

    When the issue of autonomy re-emerged in the 70s, architecture was in the peculiar
    situation of being eroded from within by having become a service industry completely
    determined by the building technology and programmatic demands of the time. On the
    other hand, it had been challenged from outside the discipline by behaviorism,
    sociology, pseudo-positivist history and pseudo-scientific discourses that tried to
    explain architecture away in terms of how people behaved, or what response they
    checked off on a questionnaire. Formal issues had given way to these statistical and
    operational analyses. Architecture found itself without cultural or disciplinary
    specificity... In contemporary vocabulary, we could say that architecture found itself
    deterritorialized. It lost its domain; it lost the cultural realm that it had controlled. It
    had to, therefore, re-territorialize itself by rediscovering, reasserting or reinventing its
    codes. (Hays, 2002)

It is possible to observe in everyday life spaces applications of insufficient or non-functioning
built environment which lack the aspects of quality; especially in terms of intrinsic and
intellectual values. Practically all of the cases has a common point of that excluding or not
giving significant attention to role of architect and urban designer in production of built
environment or even the built environment which has to be designed in order to satisfy its
users needs actually prioritize the income for those who build it. Thereby, it turns out to a
capital market rather than place to live. Besides if society does not have necessary perception
to demand the architecture which described in previous chapter; our built environments
cannot be developed, even deprogression could possibly observed as well as in the civilization itself. 
It could be summarized as “We shape our buildings and afterwards our
buildings shape us”. (Churchill, 1941)

### The Capital as Authoritative Power

The Capital mentioned as decisive power in the production of built environment. However if,
as a fact, the income is fundamental parameter of welfare; why is it should not be the
authority to shape the built environment? Briefly, because of the difference of objectives and
focus of short-term goals. Competency for the Olympics and resulted urban transformations
could be an example for the case.

    Even though the primary purpose of being a host city is to serve as the location for
    sporting events, there must be much more at stake than merely providing a venue for
    sport competitions. Much attention has been given to the economic impact and tourism
    impact of hosting the Olympics which stresses the role of the Games themselves. 'What
    has been neglected is how the Olympics are related to the long-term goals of the city.
    (Hiller, 1998)

Even if the Olympics provides reliable income and fulfill the expectations of the capital, if
not planned adaptively; providing a venue for sport competitions will result derelict gaps
within the urban texture. Therefore egocentric nature of capital economy does not prioritize
life which idealistically, the built environment should provide.

### Possible Negative Outcomes

In 21. Century by given reasons, it would be not wrong to say especially in less-developed
countries everyday built environment is lacking intrinsic, intellectual, aesthetic and even
fundamental functional requirements of place It could be said that there is a serious political
and social problem exists in this situation and its negative outcomes could also be seen by
quantitative measurements. Rigidity of built environment enforces society to fit in the
boundaries of what defined as normal[^8] ; suburbs as bleak strangling points of city, birth of
exurbs[^9] , preference to live and socialize in virtual dimensions, solitary of people living in
cities, obsession of safety, perception of city as a subject of fear, augmented perception[^10] issues
, crime and rise on mental disorders[^11] could be given as examples. By all means
non-functioning built environment may not be the only reason of those problems but should
be pointed out as one of the major reasons.

## Autonomy, Partizipation and Control Mechanisms 

When Kaufmann family asked for a house from Frank Lloyd Wright; even if they had some
expectancy in their mind, they probably did not expected that Wright will give them the
opportunity of being able live with the waterfall[^12]. Designers of built environment should 12
have their autonomy since they could decipher the multidimensional requirements of space
and create a work that capable to embody the interdisciplinary values of architecture in
singularity. However, when a system became too autonomous it may be blinded to see the
whole or be tend to exclude features easily which are valuable to others. Thus, it is important
to have control mechanisms to align and improve architectural work in order to be able to
serve society and civilization. In that point participatory design process that Jon Lang argued
could foundate the healthy built environment; but conditions could only provided by
understanding the meaning of architecture and convey it through society.

## Conclusion

Michel Foucault stunningly showed us[^13] even the most vicious practices of humanity was 13
arguably better than today in terms of providing leaks for progression. Although we are
rationalized, technologically advanced and consider ourselves as civilized; it would not be
true to say that we are progressed in every aspect. Dystopia differs from the dark times by its
completeness in which there is no more opportunity to change. On the assumption, we do not
see and solve our problems in reality then even if we do not call it, we will start to live in the
modern dystopia.

On the subject of the architecture of the 21. Century, it is crucial to point out, problems of
built environment caused by social paradoxes rather interdisciplinary or other aspects in our
reality. Since the built environment is shaped directly by politics social infrastructure has to
be revealed for being able to diagnose this ill-shaped situation. Additionally, even if it is not
the actual part of design process, since they have to bear social responsibility, architects
should contribute as curators, educators, activists and critics in order to be able to shape our
built environment in more idealistic way and advance our civilization.

# References
[1] Berleant, Arnold & Carlson, Allen (Eds.) (2006). The Aesthetics of Human Environment. Broadview Press, Ontario, Plymouth.

[2] Churchill, Winston (1943). Speech to the House of Commons (28 Oct 1943), on plans for the rebuilding of the Chamber (destroyed by an enemy bomb 10 May 1941). Never Give In! : The best of Winston Churchill’s Speeches, 2003. Hyperion, p. 358. ISBN 1401300561

[3] Foucault, Michel (1965). Madness and Civilization: History of Insanity in the Age of Reason. Translated by Richard Howard from the French. Edited by Paul Rabinow. Random House, New York, pp. ix-13 Retrieved from (7 Jan 2019) https://monoskop.org/images/1/14/Foucault_Michel_Madness_and_Civilization_A_History_of_Insanity_in_the_Age_of_Reason.pdf

[4] Foucault, Michel (1977). Discipline and Punish: The Birth of The Prison. Translated by Alan Sheridan from the French. Ransom House, New York. Retrieved from (8 Jan 2019) https://monoskop.org/images/4/43/Foucault_Michel_Discipline_and_Punish_The_Birth_of_the_Prison_1977_1995.pdf

[5] Goto, Katsushi (2017). Autonomy of Architecture, Architecture of Autonomy. Paper Presented at UIA 2017 Seoul World Architects Congress. Seoul. Retrieved From (7 Jan 2019) http://www.uia2017seoul.org/P/papers/Abstract/Paper/Poster/P-0725.pdf

[6] Hays, Michael. K. & Kogod, Lauren (Eds.) (2002). Twenty Projects at the Boundaries of the Architectural Discipline Examined in Relation to the Historical and Contemporary Debates over Autonomy. Perspecta, Vol. 33, Mining Autonomy, 2002. pp. 55-57. doi: 10.2307/1567297. Retrieved from (09 Jan 2018) https://www.jstor.org/stable/1567297

[7] Hiller, Harry H. (2007). Post-event Outcomes and the Post-modern Turn: The Olympics and Urban Transformations. The International Journal of the History of Sport Volume 25(14), 2008. doi:10.1080/16184740601154458

[8] Kuhn. Thomas S. (1962). The Structure of Scientific Revolutions (2nd Ed.). The University of Chicago Press, London. Retrieved From (4 Jan 2019) https://projektintegracija.pravo.hr/_download/repository/Kuhn_Structure_of_Scientific_Revolutions.pdf

[9] Lang, Jon (1994). Urban Design the American Experience. Van Nostrand Reinhold, New York.

[10] Le Corbusier, (1927). Towards a New Architecture. Translated by Frederick Etchells from the thirteenth French edition. Dover Publications, New York, 1986. Retrieved from (6 Jan 2019)

[11] Lynch, Kevin (1960). The Image of the City. MIT Press, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

[12] Nesbitt, Kate (1996). Theorizing A New Agenda For Architecture: An Anthology of Architectural Theory 1965-1995. Edited by Kate Nesbitt. Princeton Architectural Press, New York.

[13] Norberg-Schulz, Christian (1979). Genius Loci: Towards A Phenomenology of Architecture. Rizzoli International Publications, New York, 1980.

[14] Pava, Calvin. H. P. (1981). Towards a Concept of Normative Incrementalism: One Prospect for Purposeful Non-synoptic Change in Highly Fragmented Social Systems (Dissertation). University of Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania.

[15] Seyhun, Canan (2004). The Role of the Architect and Autonomy of Architecture: An Inquiry into the Position of the Early Modern Architect and Architecture: Le Corbusier and Maison Curutchet (Master Dissertation). Middle East Technical University, Ankara.

[16] Tyner, James A. (2012). Space Place and Violence: Violence and the Embodied Geographies of Race, Sex, and Gender. Routledge, London. pp. 18-24


[^1]: See Kate Nesbitt, Theorizing A New Agenda For Architecture: An Anthology of Architectural Theory 1965-1995. Edited by Kate Nesbitt. Princeton Architectural Press, New York. pp. 13-25.

[^2]: 2 Generation Z or Gen Z, refers to generation that typically use the mid-1990s to mid-2000s as starting birth years.

[^3]: E.g. French Revolution (1789), American Civil War (1861-65), The Indian independence movement, The Turkish War of Independence (1919-22)

[^4]: See Jon Lang, Urban Design the American Experience. Van Nostrand Reinhold, New York. Chapter 20-24

[^5]: See Arnold Berleant & Allen Carlson, The Aesthetics of Human Environment. Broadview Press, Ontario, Plymouth. Cultivating an Urban Aesthetic by Arnold Berleant and Multi Sensoriness and the City by Yrjö Sepänmaa

[^6]: An advocate of modern ideas or theories; a person characterized by modernness of thinking. Retrieved From (6 Jan 2019) https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/modernus

[^7]: Starchitect is a abbreviation used to describe architects whose celebrity and critical acclaim have transformed them into idols of the architecture world and may even have given them some degree of fame amongst the general public. Retrieved from (6 Jan 2019) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starchitect

[^8]: See Michel Foucault, Foucault, Michel (1965). Madness and Civilization: History of Insanity in the Age of Reason. Random House, New York, pp. ix-13

[^9]: A prosperous area beyond a city's suburbs.

[^10]: Augmented perception refers to incompatible condition of tracing delusional lifestyle created by media e.g. Manhattan Effect

[^11]: Entry retrieved from (7 Jan 2018) https://www.anxietycentre.com/FAQ/why-is-mental-illness-on-the-rise.shtml

[^12]: Entry retrieved from (7 Jan 2018) https://www.fallingwater.org/history/about-fallingwater/designing-fallingwater/

[^13]: See Michel Foucault, Foucault, Michel (1977). Discipline and Punish: The Birth of The Prison. Translated by Alan Sheridan from the French. Ransom House, New York.

children.value: Bu sorgulama zamansal olarak farkli noktalarda yasadigim birkac olayin birlesmesiyle olusturulmustur. Birincisi, bizim otostopcu sorunsali olarak tanimladigimiz bir problemdi. Sorun otostop ceken bir insanin kendi arabasi oldugunda otostopcu alma konusunda etik bir sorumluluk hissedip hissetmedigidir.
Ikinci sorun bilim insani olmanin on sartinin ne oldugu uzerineydi.
Kisisel tecrubemde cogu insan bilime katki sunmus olmak veya objektiviteyi kabul etmek olarak tanimladi
Tanimlarin legitimitesini farkli ve tercihen ekstrem durumlarda sinamayi seven biri olarak soyle bir ornek geldi amlima
A kisisi objektif dusunen ve bilime 1 birim katkisi olan biri fakat cikar catismasi yuzunden B kisisini engelliyor

Eger a kisisi b kisisini engellemeseydi B kisisi bilime 2 birim katki yapacakti
Bu durumda, a kisisine hala bilim insani diyebilir miyiz? Evet bilime katki yaptigi ve konvansiyonel sinirlarda objektivite sinirlari icerisinde kaldigi dogru(objektivite baska bir yazinin tartisma konusu)
Fakat A insani hic olmasaydi bizim dusunsel uzayimizda B kisisi bilime iki birim katki yapacagi icin aslinda bilimi gelistirmis degil engellemis oldu diyebilir miyiz?
Ilk tanimlari gecersiz kilan dusunce deneyi benim icin bu idi eger gercek ornegini ariyorsaniz Tesla ve Edison iliskisini inceleyebilirsiniz.
Bu noktada bir insanin yaptigi calismanin bilime katki yapmis olmasi benim nazarimda o kisiyi bilim insani olarak tnsimlamak icin yeterli degildi
Her bir nesil kendinden oncekilerin eridebildigi ve yonetebildigi kadariyla alarak kullanir
Bu calisma bir omur surse de aktarimi dakikalar alabilir.
Insanligin urettigi toplam, objektif ve gozlemlenebilir bilgi ve teorilerin tamami bilimi olusturur.
Bu noktada dikkat ddilmesi gereken bilim bir kisiye, gruba, millete veya topluma ait degildir.
Sayma sayilari dunyanin farkli yerlerinde ihtiyac olarak dogmus
Arap numeralleri ile guclu bir temsil mekanizmasi saglanmis
Omer hayyam ucuncu dereceden denklemleri cozmek icin omrunu harcamistir

Bunu kendiniz uretebileceginizi mi dusunuyorusunuz? Dil temsil mekanizlari ve butun bilgiyi dusundugunuzde hicbir insan omrunun yetmeyecegi kompleksitedeki bilgiyi kstegorize edilmis bir sekilde kullanimimiza sunularak daha cocuk yasta aliyoruz
Bu noktada bilginin uretilme ve aktilma zamanlari arasinda cok inanilmaz farklar olsbiliyor
Asirlar oncesinin en yetkin insanlarinin sahio olmadigi bilgi gunumuzde okula yeni baslayan bir cocugun elinde olsbiliyor
Bu noktada bilimin baska bir ozelligi goz onune gelir
Bilim belli bir guruhun mali veya urunu olmadigi gibi bilim ayni zamanda paylasilandir.
Siz bir bilgiyi alabilir gelistirebilir bundan yeni bir bilgi uretebilirsiniz. Fakat bunu paylasmadiginiz ve kisisel cikar amacli kullandiginiz durumda o bilgi artik ortak mali degil size ait olur
Siz size acik olani kullanarak bir bilgi uretip bunu pekala kendinize saklayabilirsiniz bunun toplum karsiliginda bir cezasi veya yaptirimi yoktur. Olmamalidir da
Fakst ortak olmayan deger bilim degildir. Gercek bilimsel bilgi public private iliskisi icerisinde public olandir.
Bilimsel bilgi elestriden sorgulanmaktan korkmaz baska birinin ilerletmesinden ya da kullanmasindan korkmaz objeitivite bunu gerektirir
bilim adami ve scientist arasindaki fark
bilim evrenseldir geri vermek ahlakli olmak on sartidir.
